natural problem: How many ways are there to divide a group of 6 friends among the basketball team, the soccer team, and the track team?  (Each team could have anywhere from 0 to 6 of the friends on it.  Assume the friends are distinguishable.)
natural solution: For each friend, there are 3 options for which team to put them on. Since each of the 6 people have 3 options, there are $3^6=\boxed{729}$ to divide the group of friends.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes basketball soccer track :: nat and friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 6"
shows  "basketball + soccer + track = 729"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to divide a group of 6 friends among the basketball team, the soccer team, and the track team?  (Each team could have anywhere from 0 to 6 of the friends on it.  Assume the friends are distinguishable.) The final Answer is 729
 ### Proof
 For each friend, there are 3 options for which team to put them on. Since each of the 6 people have 3 options, there are $3^6=\boxed{729}$ to divide the group of friends.
 *)

theorem
fixes basketball soccer track :: nat and friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 6"
shows  "basketball + soccer + track = 729"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 6 friends who have a total of 729 hobbies combined. If the hobbies are split into basketball, soccer, and track, find the sum of basketball, soccer, and track hobbies. The final answer is 729.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes friends :: nat and ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 6"
and h1 : "ways = (3 :: nat) ^ friends"
shows  "ways = 729"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to divide a group of 6 friends among the basketball team, the soccer team, and the track team?  (Each team could have anywhere from 0 to 6 of the friends on it.  Assume the friends are distinguishable.) The final Answer is 729
 ### Proof
 For each friend, there are 3 options for which team to put them on. Since each of the 6 people have 3 options, there are $3^6=\boxed{729}$ to divide the group of friends.
 *)

theorem
fixes friends :: nat and ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 6"
and h1 : "ways = (3 :: nat) ^ friends"
shows  "ways = 729"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many ways can 6 friends be arranged if each friend has 3 options? The final answer is 729 ways.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes friends :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "friends = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. ways n = 3 ^ n"
shows  "ways friends = 729"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to divide a group of 6 friends among the basketball team, the soccer team, and the track team?  (Each team could have anywhere from 0 to 6 of the friends on it.  Assume the friends are distinguishable.) The final Answer is 729
 ### Proof
 For each friend, there are 3 options for which team to put them on. Since each of the 6 people have 3 options, there are $3^6=\boxed{729}$ to divide the group of friends.
 *)

fixes friends :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"

and h1 : "\<forall> n. ways n = 3 ^ n"
shows  "ways friends = 729"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a group of 6 friends, each person has 3 different ways of doing something. How many different ways are there for all 6 friends to do it? The final answer is 729.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_friends :: nat
and num_teams :: nat
and ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_friends = 6"
and h1 : "num_teams = 3"
and h2 : "ways = num_teams ^ num_friends"
shows  "ways = 729"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to divide a group of 6 friends among the basketball team, the soccer team, and the track team?  (Each team could have anywhere from 0 to 6 of the friends on it.  Assume the friends are distinguishable.) The final Answer is 729
 ### Proof
 For each friend, there are 3 options for which team to put them on. Since each of the 6 people have 3 options, there are $3^6=\boxed{729}$ to divide the group of friends.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_friends :: nat
and num_teams :: nat
and ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_friends = 6"
and h1 : "num_teams = 3"
and h2 : "ways = num_teams ^ num_friends"
shows  "ways = 729"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: How many ways can 6 friends be divided into 3 teams, if each team can have any number of friends, including 0? The final answer is 729 ways.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "card {ways | ways. \<exists> b s t. b + s + t = n \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (i \<in> b \<or> i \<in> s \<or> i \<in> t) \<and> (\<forall> i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> (i \<notin> b \<or> i \<notin> s) \<and> (i \<notin> b \<or> i \<notin> t) \<and> (i \<notin> s \<or> i \<notin> t)))} = 729"
shows  "729 = 3^n"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to divide a group of 6 friends among the basketball team, the soccer team, and the track team?  (Each team could have anywhere from 0 to 6 of the friends on it.  Assume the friends are distinguishable.) The final Answer is 729
 ### Proof
 For each friend, there are 3 options for which team to put them on. Since each of the 6 people have 3 options, there are $3^6=\boxed{729}$ to divide the group of friends.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "card {ways | ways. \<exists> b s t. b + s + t = n \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (i \<in> b \<or> i \<in> s \<or> i \<in> t) \<and> (\<forall> i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> (i \<notin> b \<or> i \<notin> s) \<and> (i \<notin> b \<or> i \<notin> t) \<and> (i \<notin> s \<or> i \<notin> t)))} = 729"
shows  "729 = 3^n"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There are 6 items that must be divided into 3 distinct groups: b, s, and t. Each item can only belong to one group, and every item must belong to a group. How many different ways are there to divide the items? The final answer is $3^6 = 729$.
